Popular on NYMag.com Ad will collapse in seconds‚Ä¶ CLOSE March 27, 2017 03/27/2017 10:04 a.m. Senate Intel Committee Will Grill Jared Kushner About Meetings With Russian Officials By Jen Kirby Share Facebook iconShare Twitter iconTweet Google Plus iconShare Pinterest iconPin It Email iconEmail Comment iconComment Print icon Print Former NSA Michael Flynn and Jared Kushner. Photo: MANDEL NGAN/AFP/Getty Images In the middle of overhauling the federal bureaucracy and negotiating Middle East peace, Trump‚Äôs top aide and son-in-law Jared Kushner will reportedly have to squeeze in an appointment with the Senate Intelligence Committee to answer questions about meetings he set up with Russian officials. The New York Times reports Kushner organized sit-downs with the help of Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak during the presidential transition, including at least one between Kushner and the head of Russia‚Äôs state-owned development bank, which had been on the U.S. sanctions list since Kremlin encroachment in Ukraine. The Senate Intel Committee called Kushner in for a hearing as part of its broader investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, something the FBI confirmed last week that it‚Äôs also probing. According to the Times, Kushner and Michael Flynn ‚Äî who resigned as NSA for allegedly misleading Vice-President Mike Pence about the subjects of Flynn‚Äôs own discussions with Russian officials ‚Äî met with Kislyak in December in Trump Tower. They reportedly discussed how to better relations between the U.S. and Russia. Kislyak apparently asked for another meeting, but Kushner sent a deputy in his stead. And, finally, at the request of Kislyak, Kushner met with Sergey Gorkov, head of the Vnesheconombank, which is on the Ukraine-related sanctions list. The White House confirmed those meetings, and said these gatherings were part of Kushner‚Äôs routine outreach to foreign leaders during the transition. But Kushner will tell that to the Senate directly. ‚ÄúHe isn‚Äôt trying to hide anything and wants to be transparent,‚Äù said administration spokeswoman Hope Hicks. So Does That Mean President Trump is Screwed? video Please Watch This Video Of Pundits Incorrectly Pronouncing Devin Nunes‚Äô Name by Lindsey Ellefson | 5:04 pm, March 30th, 2017 ¬† New-nes? Noon-yez? Nyoon-yez? New-jes? The House Intel chairman‚Äôs last name is a pronunciation minefield pic.twitter.com/Etx5XFhjYH ‚Äî POLITICO (@politico) March 30, 2017 No one can say Devin Nunes‚Äò name, which is a problem, since he‚Äôs a major headliner in the news right now. Look no further than the above compilation from¬†Politico. Listen. Let‚Äôs go over how to pronounce it once and for all. Here is an ad from when the California congressman was running for office. He says ‚ÄúNoo-nes.‚Äù Why? Because there is no tilde¬†(~) over the second ‚Äún‚Äù in Nunes. Think back to ninth-grade Spanish class and recall that the tilde adds the ‚Äúy‚Äù sound, so it would be necessary to have the tilde if Nunes were pronounced ‚ÄúNoon-yes.‚Äù It would look like this: Nu√±es. Now you know, so don‚Äôt get it wrong again! [image via screengrab] ‚Äî‚Äî Lindsey: Twitter. Facebook. Computerworld New Zealand Staying alive: DDR5 memory is on its way News Technology News Business Cloud Computing Data Centre Gaming Dev Government Infrastructure Mobility Networking Open Source Security Servers Social Networking Software Software Development Storage Tech Planet Telecoms Tutorials Unified Comms Virtualisation Tools Blogs Editorial Contacts Events IT Media Releases Join Computerworld Newsletters NBN RSS Slideshows Vendor View Videos Zones Jobs Whitepapers All Whitepapers Business + Management Cloud Computing CRM Data Centre Data Management Disaster Recovery Network Security Storage Telecommunications Unified Communications Virtualisation Wireless Other Whitepapers Login Forgot password? Twitter Facebook Staying alive: DDR5 memory is on its way DDR5 DRAM will be two times faster than DDR4 Agam Shah (IDG News Service) 31 March, 2017 07:26 - - - - print email Comments More DDR memory is on the way, despite many predictions that its time would soon be up. Development of specifications for the new DDR5 DRAM has started, and it will be finalized next year, JEDEC, a memory standards-setting organization, said on Thursday. DDR5 will succeed the current DDR4 memory, which is used in PCs and servers. DDR5 will be two times faster than DDR4 and also more power efficient. DDR5 will also have double the density of DDR4. Typical DDR5 DIMMs will have twice the gigabyte capacity of DDR4 DIMMs. Analysts didn't expect DDR5 to be developed; instead, they thought the line for DDR DRAM would end at DDR4. But PC and server designs haven't changed much in recent years, and there could be an appetite for DDR5. It's not certain when memory makers will release DDR5 memory. But like DDR4, DDR5 may first make it into servers and high-end gaming PCs and then to laptops. A low-power form of DDR5 could make it available for mobile devices. Samsung's latest Galaxy S8 smartphones have LPDDR4 memory. Chip and motherboard makers will also have to build in support for the new DDR5 memory, and that process could take longer than a year after the specification is released. Tech vendors are developing new forms of memory to rival DDR5. Intel next year will ship Optane memory DIMMs, which could replace DDR DRAM. Optane has the advantage of being able to retain data even if a computer is shut off, something that DDR DRAM can't do. Multiple forms of DRAM alternatives have also emerged in the form of the faster HBM2 (High-Bandwidth Memory) and GDDR5X, which are mainly used in resource-hungry graphics processors. A new form of 3D memory called HMC (Hybrid Memory Cube) is used in Intel's Xeon Phi supercomputing chips. There could be a demand for DDR5 partly because applications like databases are moving to in-memory processing. Companies like Dell and Hewlett Packard Enterprise are doubling memory capacity in servers at fast rates to handle those applications. JEDEC also announced that development of the specifications for a new form of hybrid memory called NVDIMM-P is underway. NVDIMM is a form of persistent memory, which merges nonvolatile flash storage and volatile DRAM into a DIMM slot. This sort of memory is targeted at applications like databases, which use a mix of flash and DRAM for processing and caching. Join the Computerworld New Zealand newsletter! Join Error: Please check your email address. The announced breakout session speakers include representatives from ING, Intel, Tata Consultancy Services, The Glue, Redis Labs, ScaleOut Software, and WSO2. The IMC Summit Europe will take place at the M√∂venpick Hotel Amsterdam City Centre, June 20-21, 2017. Attendees can receive a 20 percent Super Saver discount on the registration fee by registering by April 23, 2017. Sponsorship opportunities are available for companies that want to reach the IMC Summit‚Äôs unique audience. The In-Memory Computing Summit Europe is the only industry-wide event focusing on the full range of in-memory computing-related technologies. It brings together computing visionaries, decision makers, experts and developers for the purpose of education, discussion and networking. Breakout sessions for the event will include: Addressing 21st Century Data Challenges with 21st Century Technologies ‚Äî a Case from the Financial Markets ‚Äî Tim Wood, IT Manager High Performance Computing and Model Integration, ING In-Persistent-Memory Computing ‚Äî Ken Gibson, Director SW Architecture, Intel Cloud Platforms Group, Intel Corp. Next Generation Trade Surveillance System Using In-Memory Computing Technologies ‚Äî Nishant Agrawal, Scientist, Tata Consultancy Services, Ltd. Delivering Machine Learning in Real-Time with In-Memory Computing ‚Äî Cihan Biyikoglu, VP Product Management, Redis Labs, Inc. Creating a Dynamically Re-Configurable Event-Driven Architecture for Financial Services ‚Äî Danny Goovaerts, CTO, The Glue Stream Processing with In-Memory Data Grids: Creating the Digital Twin ‚Äî William Bain, CEO, ScaleOut Software Redefining Business with Streaming Analytics ‚Äî Seshika Fernando, Senior Technical Lead, WSO2 Super Saver Registration Discounts Attendees can receive a 20 percent discount by registering early. The Super Saver General Admission rate of EUR 399 ends on April 23, 2017. Register via the conference website, or email attendance and registration questions to info@imcsummit.org. Sponsorships By sponsoring the In-Memory Computing Summit Europe, organizations gain a unique opportunity to enhance their visibility and reputation as leaders in in-memory computing products and services. They can interact with key in-memory computing business and technical decision makers, connect with technology purchasers and influencers, and help shape the future of Fast Data. Sponsorship packages are still available. Visit the conference website for more information on sponsorship benefits and pricing and to download a prospectus. Current sponsors include: Platinum Sponsors ‚Äî GridGain Systems Gold Sponsors ‚Äî ScaleOut Software Silver Sponsors ‚Äî Fujitsu, Hazelcast About the In-Memory Computing Summit The In-Memory Computing Summits in Europe and North America are the only industry-wide events tailored to in-memory computing-related technologies and solutions. They are the perfect opportunity to connect with technical IT decision makers, IT implementers, and developers who make or influence purchasing decisions in the areas of in-memory computing, Big Data, Fast Data, IoT and HPC. Attendees include CEOs, CIOs, CTOs, VPs, IT directors, IT managers, data scientists, senior engineers, senior developers, architects and more. The Summits are unique forums for networking, education and the exchange of ideas ‚Äî ideas that power the new world and future of Fast Data. For more information, visit https://imcsummit.org and follow the event on Twitter @IMCSummit. About GridGain Systems GridGain Systems is revolutionizing real-time data access and processing by offering enterprise-grade in-memory computing solutions built on Apache¬Æ Ignite‚Ñ¢. GridGain solutions are used by global enterprises in financial, software, ecommerce, retail, online business services, healthcare, telecom and other major sectors. GridGain solutions connect data stores (SQL, NoSQL and Apache¬Æ Hadoop¬Æ) with cloud-scale applications and enable massive data throughput and ultra-low latencies across a scalable, distributed cluster of commodity servers. GridGain is the most comprehensive, enterprise-grade in-memory computing platform for high volume ACID transactions, real-time analytics and hybrid transactional/analytical processing. LinkedIn Twitter YouTube Facebook Google Plus Send Us E-mail Privacy Policy [Updated 3 Mar 14] Advertising CSO Subscribe to emails Subscribe to IDG Publications Contact Us Menu CIO Staying alive: DDR5 memory is on its way Staying alive: DDR5 memory is on its way DDR5 DRAM will be two times faster than DDR4 Agam Shah (IDG News Service) 31 March, 2017 07:26 - - - - print email Comments More DDR memory is on the way, despite many predictions that its time would soon be up. Development of specifications for the new DDR5 DRAM has started, and it will be finalized next year, JEDEC, a memory standards-setting organization, said on Thursday. DDR5 will succeed the current DDR4 memory, which is used in PCs and servers. DDR5 will be two times faster than DDR4 and also more power efficient. DDR5 will also have double the density of DDR4. Typical DDR5 DIMMs will have twice the gigabyte capacity of DDR4 DIMMs. Analysts didn't expect DDR5 to be developed; instead, they thought the line for DDR DRAM would end at DDR4. But PC and server designs haven't changed much in recent years, and there could be an appetite for DDR5. It's not certain when memory makers will release DDR5 memory. But like DDR4, DDR5 may first make it into servers and high-end gaming PCs and then to laptops. A low-power form of DDR5 could make it available for mobile devices. Samsung's latest Galaxy S8 smartphones have LPDDR4 memory. Chip and motherboard makers will also have to build in support for the new DDR5 memory, and that process could take longer than a year after the specification is released. Tech vendors are developing new forms of memory to rival DDR5. Intel next year will ship Optane memory DIMMs, which could replace DDR DRAM. Optane has the advantage of being able to retain data even if a computer is shut off, something that DDR DRAM can't do. Multiple forms of DRAM alternatives have also emerged in the form of the faster HBM2 (High-Bandwidth Memory) and GDDR5X, which are mainly used in resource-hungry graphics processors. A new form of 3D memory called HMC (Hybrid Memory Cube) is used in Intel's Xeon Phi supercomputing chips. There could be a demand for DDR5 partly because applications like databases are moving to in-memory processing. Companies like Dell and Hewlett Packard Enterprise are doubling memory capacity in servers at fast rates to handle those applications. JEDEC also announced that development of the specifications for a new form of hybrid memory called NVDIMM-P is underway. NVDIMM is a form of persistent memory, which merges nonvolatile flash storage and volatile DRAM into a DIMM slot. This sort of memory is targeted at applications like databases, which use a mix of flash and DRAM for processing and caching. ‚ÄãCIO Executive Council member profile: Emmanuel Steve Dulvin More from CIO Executive Council Join the CIO Australia group on LinkedIn. By Agam Shah U.S. Correspondent, IDG News Service | Mar 30, 2017 1:26 PM PT Credit: HPE More like this DRAM to live on as DDR5 memory Adoption of DDR4 memory facing delays Intel ships first Optane memory modules for testing Video CW@50: 50 years of storage More DDR memory is on the way, despite many predictions that its time would soon be up. Development of specifications for the new DDR5 DRAM has started, and it will be finalized next year, JEDEC, a memory standards-setting organization, said on Thursday. DDR5 will succeed the current DDR4 memory, which is used in PCs and servers. DDR5 will be two times faster than DDR4 and also more power efficient. DDR5 will also have double the density of DDR4. Typical DDR5 DIMMs will have twice the gigabyte capacity of DDR4 DIMMs. Analysts didn't expect DDR5 to be developed; instead, they thought the line for DDR DRAM would end at DDR4. But PC and server designs haven't changed much in recent years, and there could be an appetite for DDR5. It's not certain when memory makers will release DDR5 memory. But like DDR4, DDR5 may first make it into servers and high-end gaming PCs and then to laptops. A low-power form of DDR5 could make it available for mobile devices. Samsung's latest Galaxy S8 smartphones have LPDDR4 memory. Chip and motherboard makers will also have to build in support for the new DDR5 memory, and that process could take longer than a year after the specification is released. Tech vendors are developing new forms of memory to rival DDR5. Intel next year will ship Optane memory DIMMs, which could replace DDR DRAM. Optane has the advantage of being able to retain data even if a computer is shut off, something that DDR DRAM can't do. Multiple forms of DRAM alternatives have also emerged in the form of the faster HBM2 (High-Bandwidth Memory) and GDDR5X, which are mainly used in resource-hungry graphics processors. A new form of 3D memory called HMC (Hybrid Memory Cube) is used in Intel's Xeon Phi supercomputing chips. There could be a demand for DDR5 partly because applications like databases are moving to in-memory processing. Companies like Dell and Hewlett Packard Enterprise are doubling memory capacity in servers at fast rates to handle those applications. JEDEC also announced that development of the specifications for a new form of hybrid memory called NVDIMM-P is underway. NVDIMM is a form of persistent memory, which merges nonvolatile flash storage and volatile DRAM into a DIMM slot. This sort of memory is targeted at applications like databases, which use a mix of flash and DRAM for processing and caching. Music News Entertainment Politics Features Share < br />this article: Sean Spicer inadvertently leaked how many sources Nunes met on White House grounds In News by Maggie Serota / March 30, 2017 Share < br />this article: Follow @maggieserota At the White House daily press briefing, Sean Spicer loves chastising reporters over how they should be focusing on the people leaking information on the Trump administration and not the substance of those leaks. Now it looks like Spicer is one of those leakers, even if it‚Äôs just by accident. On Thursday, The New York Times broke¬†the news that House Intel Committee chair Devin Nunes had met with two White House sources ‚Äî Ezra Cohen-Watnick, the senior director for intelligence at the National Security Council and Michael Ellis, a lawyer in the White House Counsel‚Äôs Office ‚Äî before he ran off to President Trump to inform him of intelligence agencies picking up incidental surveillance of Trump transition team members while investigating foreign targets. Prior to this story, it was unknown just how many White House sources Nunes met with or whom he met with on White House grounds the evening prior to making the surveillance announcement to the press. During Tuesday‚Äôs briefing, Spicer was asked if he knew who cleared Nunes for entry onto the White House grounds. Here‚Äôs his response, emphasis mine: But when the information that is occurring now, which is two individuals who were properly cleared ‚Äî or three, or whoever [Nunes] met with, I don‚Äôt know ‚Äî¬†that they are sharing stuff that is entirely legal with the appropriate clearances ‚Äî and then there is an obsession on the process. Spicer admitted that Nunes met with two sources on White House grounds, realized what he did, then said ‚Äúor three‚Äù and then realized he fucked up further so he buttoned his verbal ass spray with ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know.‚Äù Smooth. He did it not only once, but twice! Granted, the below quote (‚Äútwo individuals‚Äù) could refer to just Nunes meeting with one source, but the ‚Äúhowever many‚Äù that follows feels like he‚Äôs just covering his tracks again: And it‚Äôs sort of ‚Äî it‚Äôs a backwards way that when you all report on stuff with sources that are leaking ‚Äî illegally leaking classified information, that‚Äôs appropriate and fine. No one questions that ‚Äî the substance and material. When two individuals, or however many are engaged in this process, have a discussion that is 100 percent legal and appropriate and cleared, suddenly the obsession becomes about the process and not the substance. During Thursday‚Äôs presser, Spicer told reporters that he didn‚Äôt know whom Nunes met with during his clandestine White House meeting, but that seems unlikely given that he seemed to know how many people the House Intel Committee chair¬†did. Email a friend To Use commas to separate multiple email addresses From 
		     Privacy Policy Thank you Your message has been sent. Sorry There was an error emailing this page. By Agam Shah U.S. Correspondent, IDG News Service | Mar 30, 2017 1:34 PM PT Credit: HPE More like this DRAM will live on as DDR5 memory is slated to reach computers in 2020 Adoption of DDR4 memory faces delays Intel ships first Optane memory modules for testing Video Nvidia's mighty GeForce GTX 1080 Ti cranks PC gaming to 11 More DDR memory is on the way, despite many predictions that its time would soon be up. Development of specifications for the new DDR5 DRAM has started, and it will be finalized next year, JEDEC, a memory standards-setting organization, said on Thursday. DDR5 will succeed the current DDR4 memory, which is used in PCs and servers. DDR5 will be two times faster than DDR4 and also more power efficient. DDR5 will also have double the density of DDR4. Typical DDR5 DIMMs will have twice the gigabyte capacity of DDR4 DIMMs. Analysts didn't expect DDR5 to be developed; instead, they thought the line for DDR DRAM would end at DDR4. But PC and server designs haven't changed much in recent years, and there could be an appetite for DDR5. It's not certain when memory makers will release DDR5 memory. But like DDR4, DDR5 may first make it into servers and high-end gaming PCs and then to laptops. A low-power form of DDR5 could make it available for mobile devices. Samsung's latest Galaxy S8 smartphones have LPDDR4 memory. Chip and motherboard makers will also have to build in support for the new DDR5 memory, and that process could take longer than a year after the specification is released. Tech vendors are developing new forms of memory to rival DDR5. Intel next year will ship Optane memory DIMMs, which could replace DDR DRAM. Optane has the advantage of being able to retain data even if a computer is shut off, something that DDR DRAM can't do. Multiple forms of DRAM alternatives have also emerged in the form of the faster HBM2 (High-Bandwidth Memory) and GDDR5X, which are mainly used in resource-hungry graphics processors. A new form of 3D memory called HMC (Hybrid Memory Cube) is used in Intel's Xeon Phi supercomputing chips. There could be a demand for DDR5 partly because applications like databases are moving to in-memory processing. Companies like Dell and Hewlett Packard Enterprise are doubling memory capacity in servers at fast rates to handle those applications. JEDEC also announced that development of the specifications for a new form of hybrid memory called NVDIMM-P is underway. NVDIMM is a form of persistent memory, which merges nonvolatile flash storage and volatile DRAM into a DIMM slot. This sort of memory is targeted at applications like databases, which use a mix of flash and DRAM for processing and caching. Trump set to sign executive orders to stop trade abuses Finance ‚Äî 3h 6m ago Diplomats instructed to 'avoid eye contact' with Tillerson: report Blog Briefing Room ‚Äî 3h 31m ago Report: Trump tax policy would largely benefit New York's wealthy Finance ‚Äî 3h 45m ago Intel Dem: Innocent people don't seek immunity Blog Briefing Room ‚Äî 4h 12m ago Dems react to Flynn's request for immunity: 'Where there's smoke, there's fire' News ‚Äî 4h 18m ago Ex-ethics lawyer to George W. Bush: I'm renaming pet canary after Flynn In The Know ‚Äî 4h 47m ago Trump nominates officials for VA, border control Administration ‚Äî 6h 2m ago Sessions: Convictions likely needed to end government leaks Blog Briefing Room ‚Äî 6h 4m ago view all ¬† White House invites House Intel Dem to view documents By Katie Bo Williams - 03/30/17 04:04 PM EDT 1,065 ¬† ¬© Greg Nash The White House has invited the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee to view materials related to incidental collection after his Republican counterpart visited the White House last week, he told reporters. But it's unclear if the documents Rep. Adam SchiffAdam SchiffSenate Intel panel tells WH to send Russia information directly Overnight Cybersecurity: Senate Intel holds Russia hearing | WH struggles to respond to latest Nunes development | Trump extends Obama cyber threat order White House invites House Intel Dem to view documents MORE (D-Calif.) has been invited to view are the same mystery documents seen by Rep. Devin Nunes (R-Calif.), the chairman of the House panel, Schiff said. Schiff said he has accepted the invitation from the White House Counsel, but said the invitation "raises¬†far¬†more questions than¬†any¬†it answers." He added that he has pushed for the entire committee to have access to the materials. ADVERTISEMENT White House press secretary Sean Spicer said that the White House had¬†invited leaders¬†of both the House and Senate intelligence committees to review materials related to their investigations into Russian interference in the election.¬† But Schiff did not appear mollified by the White House's invitation, commenting hours after a¬†New York Times report¬†identified two National Security Council (NSC) staff members who it said helped Nunes acquire the information. Schiff said if that was the case ‚Äî and these are the same documents provided to Nunes ‚Äî it is "bewildering" that the information wasn't simply taken directly to the president. "Why all the cloak and dagger stuff?" he said.¬† "They don't need our chairman to deliver something to the president they can deliver themselves," Schiff said. "The White House needs to answer is this instead a case in which to effectively launder information through our committee to avoid [revealing] the true source of the information." Nunes earlier this month said he had been shown information indicating that the U.S. intelligence community had incidentally collected information on members of President Trump's transition team and subsequently unmasked that information, perhaps inappropriately. The GOP chairman was shown the information while on White House grounds last week. The next day, he briefed Speaker Paul RyanPaul Ryan6 reasons 'TrumpCare' flatlined Overnight Healthcare: Ryan says key ObamaCare payments will continue during House lawsuit White House invites House Intel Dem to view documents MORE (R-Wis.), held a press conference announcing his discovery, and then trekked back to the White House to brief Trump on the information. Democrats have accused the chairman of acting as an agent of the White House, perhaps to provide substantiation for Trump's claim that the Obama administration "wiretapped" him during the campaign ‚Äî a charge Nunes has¬†vehemently denied.¬† The¬†incident ‚Äî along with the cancelation of a public hearing involving former Obama administration officials ‚Äî has thrown a wrench into the committee's investigation into Russian interference in the election.¬† Schiff and other Democrats have called for Nunes to recuse himself from the investigation and work on the committee was effectively halted this week.¬† Earlier in the day, Schiff told reporters that Democrats had determined to¬†proceed with the probe,¬†following a week of speculation that the minority might walk away in protest.¬† In one sign of¬†slightly thawed relations, Schiff said that Democrats have signed on to a letter from Republicans inviting FBI Director James Comey to return to testify before the committee behind closed doors.¬† Democrats had originally resisted signing the invitation because it conflicted with the originally-scheduled public hearing involving former acting Attorney General Sally Yates.¬† He said Republicans have not yet signed on to a request from Democrats to reschedule that hearing ‚Äî but that he has accepted the chairman's claim that the only obstacle is a desire to hold the closed session with Comey first.¬† But Schiff's manner¬†Thursday¬†afternoon remained grave. He¬†vowed that the uproar over the chairman's actions would not "distract" from the core mission of the committee's investigation.¬† "This issue is not going to distract us from doing our Russia investigation," he said. Schiff gave no timeline for when he will travel to the White House to view the documents. Updated: 4:53 p.m. Tags Adam Schiff Paul Ryan ¬† View the discussion thread. ITProPortal Search RSS News Features Analysis Guides Reviews Categories Business Hardware Security Software Mobile Enterprise Cloud Networks Public Sector Startups Web Data centre design is on the cusp of an OCP-led revolution By Greg McCulloch Feature¬† The Open Compute Project aims to make future data centres more efficient and cost effective. Shares It‚Äôs a truism in modern technology that the only constant is relentless change. However, anyone looking at data centre blueprints over the last two decades with this mindset would be in for something of a shock. In a world where innovation is a ubiquitous buzzword and cloud computing has changed many aspects of data centre usage, data centre design has largely remained the same. There are good reasons for this stasis - but with the progress of the Open Compute Project (OCP), this could, and indeed should, radically change. ¬†¬† The economics of running a data centre have traditionally relied on getting as much value as possible from each square metre of space within it whilst keeping the whole system cool enough to be functional. Especially in areas where land values are high, for example in London, the efficiency and therefore the profitability of the data centre leans on the design and layout of the infrastructure and the clever management of these factors. This has historically led to a standardised design approach amongst most data centres, give or take marginal differences. However, developments from the work of the OCP are slowly changing the assumptions at the core of data centre design ‚Äì for those who are paying attention to it.¬† Currently, any data centre designer or architect is compelled to reserve a large part of the data centre blueprint to the rooms that house the uninterruptible power supplies (UPS), batteries, and generator. These fail safes guarantee the data centre‚Äôs functionality regardless of most mechanical and electrical errors that can occur, and the room where they are housed is arguably one of the most vital rooms in any data centre. It also represents a very large investment, both in terms of CapEx and OpEx costs. Meanwhile, the need for raised floor cooling in order to efficiently prevent the building from overheating eats further into data centre space. Data centre real estate is a fixed asset that data centre operators need to maximise ‚Äì and the above factors represent big restrictions on what can and can‚Äôt be done. ¬†¬† Enter the OCP - founded by Facebook, Microsoft, Intel, Rackspace, and Goldman Sachs, its mission is to alter how data centres are built with the goal of making them more efficient and cost-effective. IT infrastructure has historically been a ‚Äòblack box‚Äô, proprietary to its owners and inaccessible to everyone else. Where ideas are kept separate and siloed, new ways of doing things can‚Äôt evolve, and it is this that the OCP is attacking. It has taken the creativity spawned by the collaborative and accessible spirit of the open source software movement and applied it to data centre hardware, with exciting results. ¬†¬† Two of its key innovations directly challenge the assumptions underpinning data centre design by altering the requirements mentioned above. OCP technologists have discovered a way to condense the battery into the server whilst retaining the functionality of both, reducing the need for a separate room with a centralised UPS system. Meanwhile, new ways of cooling the data centre solely using environmental and ambient elements erode the need for raised floor ceiling and take back yet more real estate. More room in the data centre means more space to focus on efficiency and innovation measures.¬† Yet change is never simply a matter of technical possibilities. To achieve significant change and a break from the standard behaviour of the past, you need to alter people‚Äôs ways of thinking and take into account the human element. As emphasised earlier, the current norm for data centre design has become entrenched in the collective mind of the data centre industry over a period of around two decades. Few third-party data centres would automatically break with years of habit and normalised behavior to design a data centre without a UPS, generator, and battery room, or a raised floor. The need for these things is embedded in the industry‚Äôs way of thinking and the current mind-set is that these elements are absolutely necessary to keep the site running in the event of a power failure. Changing this view will be a long process ‚Äì regardless how much black site testing is done.¬† The key to changing mindsets is developing a set of norms around the use of OCP hardware and educating the industry. Although terms such as ‚ÄòOCP ready‚Äô are already being heard around the industry, these are not always so helpful, especially as the Project themselves have yet to set out a clear. The terminology so far only conveys to potential customers that the data centre in question is capable of using OCP optimised hardware. There needs to be a standard which communicates clearly that physical alterations have been made to a site that enable it to take full advantage of OCP innovations. Data centre luminaries from Intel, Facebook, and Microsoft, amongst others, are working together on the OCP board to devise the parameters by which suitability for OCP hardware can be accessed and therefore a informative new standard for OCP optimised data centres can be unveiled.¬† Conventional thinking can be overturned by education, and this will undoubtedly play a key role in helping data centre operators to rethink the possibilities of design and infrastructure. The first task of the OCP is to set out clear definitions of an ‚ÄòOCP Ready‚Äô or ‚ÄòOCP Optimised‚Äù data centre. Once this has been achieved then data centre managers and designers can work towards these parameters. This will make it possible for the industry to conceive of a data centre without a UPS, battery, and generator room, as well as without raised-floor cooling. However, by illustrating the vast possibilities that these innovations can create, attitudes can slowly be shifted and correspondingly data centre design can be modified. Slowly but surely, we will see OCP start to make an impact as a key part of modern IT infrastructure.¬† Image Credit: Scanrail1 / Shutterstock ¬† Topics Cloud software data centres open compute project it infrastructure GET YOUR FREE MAGAZINE NET: The Money Issue worth ¬£5.99 Join over 7000 ITProPortal subscribers! Author: Issie Lapowsky. Issie Lapowsky Business Date of Publication: 03.30.17. 03.30.17 Time of Publication: 2:06 pm. 2:06 pm A Silicon Valley Lawmaker‚Äôs $1 Trillion Plan to Save Trump Country Jim Wilson/The New York Times The Trump administration may not believe that automation threatens today‚Äôs American workforce, but try telling that to a travel agent or a truck driver or a factory worker or an accountant. One recent study found that for every one robot introduced to the workforce, six related human jobs disappear. But those six humans still need to get by. That‚Äôs why many Silicon Valley leaders, even as they innovate entire industries and livelihoods out of existence, have started gravitating toward a not-so-new concept: basic income. Under the idea, the government would provide every citizen with a stipend, no strings attached. Especially in times of economic upheaval, when technological change is both rampant and unpredictable, the thinking goes, a basic income would ensure a baseline of stability. Now the Valley‚Äôs newest congressional representative is bringing the idea to Washington, to the tune of $1 trillion. Democrat Ro Khanna of California‚Äôs 17th district‚Äîhome to companies like Apple and Intel‚Äîwould seem to have little chance of persuading the most conservative Congress in memory to blithely give away so much money. But there‚Äôs a wrinkle: The biggest beneficiaries wouldn‚Äôt be Khanna‚Äôs well-heeled constituents in Cupertino or Santa Clara. It‚Äôs President Trump‚Äôs core supporters in rural America who would have the most to gain. Related Stories Joseph Bien-Kahn Trump Can‚Äôt Deliver the Rust Belt Jobs He Promised Because Work Has Changed Maya Rockeymoore Cutting Social Services Only Makes the Robotic Takeover Worse Vasant Dhar Robots Will Soon Do Your Taxes. Bye-Bye, Accounting Jobs Clive Thompson The Next Big Blue-Collar Job Is Coding Khanna is preparing to introduce a bill that he calls ‚Äúthe biggest move in orders of magnitude‚Äù toward providing a basic income in the US. Specifically, it proposes a $1 trillion expansion of the earned income tax credit, which would roughly double the amount of money going into low-income families‚Äô pockets. The main difference between Khanna‚Äôs plan and the Silicon Valley utopianists‚Äô version of basic income is that for now recipients would still have to have a job to qualify. Think of it more as a basic income warm-up. Khanna, a former Stanford economist who briefly worked for the Commerce Department under President Obama and supported Bernie Sanders for president, knows Congress will probably (ok, definitely) never go for it. For now, that‚Äôs fine by him. You could think of his plan as a kind of political moonshot. As with Google Glass, it‚Äôs a bold idea that may not catch on in the mainstream. But simply injecting the idea into public conversation propels it forward until people finally find it palatable (hello, Snap Spectacles). ‚ÄúThe criticism of the Democrats in the past is that they were too timid. They ran on consultant-driven platitudes and didn‚Äôt offer a compelling enough vision,‚Äù Khanna told me as he sipped cappuccino from a paper cup inside New York‚Äôs Chelsea Market building one crisp morning in March. ‚ÄúAs we saw with this election, people are attracted to bold clear ideas.‚Äù But the boldest part of Khanna‚Äôs plan isn‚Äôt merely what it will cost a budget-conscious Congress. According to the Tax Policy Center, which assisted Khanna in crafting this bill, this plan would compensate the bottom 20 percent of earners for wage stagnation dating back to 1979. Currently a family with one child earning below a certain income threshold receives a $3,400 earned income tax credit. Under Khanna‚Äôs plan, they would get roughly twice that. The more kids you have, the more money you get. And you don‚Äôt need to dig too far into a map of average incomes across the US to see where that 20 percent lives. Hint: It ain‚Äôt Silicon Valley. Instead, the plan, if it worked as promised, would especially benefit states like Arkansas, Mississippi, and West Virginia‚Äîin other words, Trump Country. Coders in Coal Country Khanna became Silicon Valley‚Äôs newest voice in Washington in November after ousting incumbent Mike Honda, a member of Congress since 2001, in an acrimonious primary. It was Khanna‚Äôs second time running, and his insurgent campaign earned support from techies like Facebook‚Äôs Sheryl Sandberg, Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai, and yes, even billionaire Trump supporter Peter Thiel, who admired Khanna‚Äôs attempt to unseat a career politician. ‚ÄúPeter Thiel and I disagree on 99 percent of things,‚Äù Khanna said stiffly, aware of the seeming contradiction that a devout libertarian like Thiel would contribute to his campaign. ‚ÄúBut he wants robust, spirited debate.‚Äù Support for basic income also doesn‚Äôt break down along the usual party lines. The idea of a guaranteed income originated with libertarian economist and Reagan administration advisor Milton Friedman, who called it a ‚Äúnegative income tax‚Äù and argued it would ‚Äúdispense with the vast bureaucracy‚Äù that dictates welfare programs. At the same time, some progressives argue that basic income would undermine need-based welfare programs and the more important priority of creating jobs. ‚ÄòThis idea you‚Äôre going to take a 50-year-old coal miner and turn them into a software engineer is ridiculous. That‚Äôs sometimes how the Democratic message came out.‚Äô Ro Khanna During his short stint in office so far, Khanna also has not followed the most conventional path. For a congressman whose district is home to billionaires and boasts a median annual income of more than $111,000, he has shown an unusual fixation on crafting policy for the country‚Äôs rural poor. For too long, he says, the tech industry has not heeded President Kennedy‚Äôs call to ‚Äúask not what your country can do for you.‚Äù Over the years, the industry has done a lot of asking: for regulatory changes, for high-skilled worker visas, for privacy protections, for net neutrality, for patent reform. To be sure, all of those things help the tech industry thrive. But Khanna says the November election reminded tech leaders that America is a big country, and the tech sector needs to use its power to help Americans who live outside of the industry‚Äôs narrow, coastal enclaves. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want a populist backlash,‚Äù Khanna said of his constituents. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt want a country divided by place.‚Äù Khanna believes there‚Äôs little the tech industry can do about such divisions if its leaders continue to cling to the coasts. Shortly after taking office, Khanna traveled to Paintsville, Kentucky, to check out a program that teaches people in Appalachia, many of them the children of coal miners, to code. It also connects them with jobs once they finish. Scaling such programs will be critical to equipping the next generation with the skills they need in a tech-centric economy. At the same time, Khanna acknowledges that Democrats especially can‚Äôt rest on the notion that code can fix everyone‚Äôs economic woes. Certainly older workers who bought into President Trump‚Äôs message about reviving manufacturing didn‚Äôt buy it. ‚ÄúThis idea you‚Äôre going to take a 50-year-old coal miner and turn them into a software engineer is ridiculous,‚Äù Khanna says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs sometimes how the Democratic message came out.‚Äù A Not So Modest Proposal Khanna believes expanding the safety net through the earned income tax credit, a kind of basic income precursor, could help provide more comprehensive support for people caught up in the economic turmoil spurred by automation. And in that, he‚Äôs not exactly alone. Last year, President Obama and House Speaker Paul Ryan both proposed expansions of the credit that would benefit childless workers. But the more radical idea of a basic income‚Äîwhich is to say, giving away free money‚Äîhas failed to take hold in the United States especially, as lawmakers fear it would dampen people‚Äôs incentive to work. Even Khanna agrees these kinds of subsidies should be tied to work. It‚Äôs a less radical approach to a basic income, which is why there are optimists like liberal economist Robert Reich who believe Khanna‚Äôs plan might just have a shot, particularly at a time when Trump‚Äôs base comprises the people would seem likely to benefit most. ‚ÄúUnless the party has become brainlessly ideological, one would think that this concept would appeal to many of them,‚Äù says Reich, who has also been working with Khanna on the plan. The congressman holds no such illusions. Not only would it cost $1 trillion‚Äîa hard sell as the Trump administration is gutting the federal budget‚Äîbut Khanna proposes paying for it with a financial transaction tax, even as the administration rolls back Wall Street regulations. But getting a bill passed isn‚Äôt really the point. Khanna says Ryan gave Democrats a blueprint for how to operate as the opposition party, and now that the Democrats are out of power, he‚Äôs following it. ‚ÄúHe was proposing budgets into the wilderness,‚Äù Khanna said of Ryan‚Äôs approach, ‚Äúbut then they became a real part of the conversation.‚Äù For Khanna, the Democrats lost in 2016 because they failed to lay out a clear vision. Whether or not the party ultimately gets behind basic income as part of that vision, Khanna believes Democrats must say what they‚Äôre for, not just who they‚Äôre against. Until they win back power, most Democratic proposals will remain hypothetical. They might as well be daring, too. Go Back to Top. Articles & Reviews News Archive Forums Premium Categories Computers Display Drivers GPUs / Graphics Cards Linux Gaming Memory Motherboards CPUs / Processors Software Storage Operating Systems Peripherals Close Articles & Reviews News Archive Forums Premium Categories Computers GPUs / Graphics Cards Linux Gaming Memory Motherboards CPUs / Processors Software Storage Operating Systems Peripherals Mesa 17.0.3 Being Prepped With 30+ Fixes Written by Michael Larabel in Mesa on 30 March 2017 at 12:39 PM EDT. Add A Comment Andres Gomez of Igalia has stepped up to the plate to manage Mesa 17.0.3 as the newest Mesa stable update. The plan is to release it officially by the end of week while today the release candidate is available. Over Mesa 17.0.2, the 17.0.3 update currently has 32 patches queued but potentially more may still make it into this next release. The fixes include problems with the GLSL compiler, the Intel OpenGL and Vulkan drivers, Nouveau performance improvements, RADV fixes, and various other fixes. More details on the Mesa 17.0.3 release candidate can be found via mesa-announce. Mesa 17.0.3 is currently scheduled for release on Saturday, 1 April. Mesa 17.1 as the next feature update is due out in May. Add A Comment Tweet About The Author Michael Larabel is the principal author of Phoronix.com and founded the site in 2004 with a focus on enriching the Linux hardware experience. Michael has written more than 10,000 articles covering the state of Linux hardware support, Linux performance, graphics drivers, and other topics. Michael is also the lead developer of the Phoronix Test Suite, Phoromatic, and OpenBenchmarking.org automated benchmarking software. He can be followed via Twitter or contacted via MichaelLarabel.com. Quick, Rapid, Turbo, And Fast Charging Explained: What You Need To Know About Charging Your Smartphone David Ruddock Follow View All Posts 2015/06/12 12:36pm PDTJun 12, 2015 367 Plus 1 on G+ 326 Share on Facebook 3 Share on Twitter Total Shares696 Other Reviews You've probably heard of quick charging, turbo charging, adaptive fast charging, rapid charging, and Qualcomm Quick Charge 2.0 before - or at least one or two of these things. What you may not know is that all of them are actually basically the same thing, based on the same licensed technology from Qualcomm known as Quick Charge. With that basic premise in mind, what I want to dispel in this article is the notion that you need an OEM-branded charger to get the maximum charging speed out of your smartphone, because this generally isn't true. And understanding that could save you a fair bit of money, especially if your phone doesn't come with a quick charger, or you need a second one for work or travel. First, let's talk about what Qualcomm's Quick Charge is. The basic thing you need to know is that "Quick Charge" is just a marketing term for the capabilities of the power management circuitry in your smartphone and wall charger. That means both your phone and your charger need to support quick charging in order for it to work. And no, that does not mean your phone needs a Qualcomm processor - quick charge support in end devices is contingent on only the power controller, not the larger chipset. Qualcomm has licensed the technology to non-Qualcomm smartphones like the Galaxy S6 (Exynos) and ZenFone 2 (Intel). As far as how it works, quick charging allows you to dump a lot of power into your battery by using higher-than-normal voltage until it reaches what's called "saturation" - usually around 60-80% charge depending on how the phone's power management is configured. At that point, the phone's power controller scales back the amount of power it's receiving and your phone will begin to charge more and more slowly as it approaches 100%. This is where the "adaptive" language comes from in Samsung's fast charge marketing - quick charging allows your phone to intelligently scale the amount of power it takes from the charger based on the current charge state of the battery. So, how do you know if your phone supports quick charging? You'll need to do some research on the web. You're going to have to consult Qualcomm's Quick Charge website or your device manufacturer if you want to know for sure without actually trying a quick charger. There are lists of phones with this technology out there - Qualcomm has a very good one that you can find right here - so if you're not sure, just do a little digging - it shouldn't be difficult information to find. Just remember that Quick Charge 2.0, quick charging, fast charging, adaptive fast charging, and turbo charging - they're all usually going to be referring to the same thing. Now, by usually, I mean that there are essentially two generations of quick charging out there. You have the Qualcomm Quick Charge 1.0 devices, most of which came out in 2013 and early 2014 - phones like the Galaxy S5, Note 3, the first-gen Moto X, the Nexus 5, and a handful of others. These phones don't charge as quickly as Quick Charge 2.0 devices, but they should charge at full Quick Charge 1.0 speeds when using a Quick Charge 2.0 charger, so there's at least backwards compatibility. Quick Charge 1.0 isn't on many new phones anymore, so it's not really as relevant to discuss - what you need to know is basically just that Quick Charge 1.0 isn't as fast as Quick Charge 2.0. How much slower is it? Qualcomm says it's around half the speed of Quick Charge 2.0 if you're charging from 0% for 30 minutes on a device that's turned off. It's worth noting, though, that the difference is probably proportionally less if you were to do, say, a 50 to 100% charge, because of the saturation effect and intelligent scaling. Quick Charge 2.0 is the technology you see on the Galaxy S6, S6 Edge, the LG G4, the One M8, M9, the Note 4 and Note Edge, the ASUS ZenFone 2, the Moto X 2014, the Nexus 6, the DROID Turbo, and the list goes on and on. Like I said, check out the document Qualcomm has (here) if you want a complete listing of supported devices, because there are quite a few. All of these phones, when using a Quick Charge 2.0 charger, are going to charge at basically the same speed relative to the rated capacity of their batteries. It shouldn't matter what brand the charger is - if it's a Qualcomm Quick Charge 2.0 certified charger, it's going to work and charge at the full rated speed a modern phone will allow. It's possible in the future faster chargers will emerge (ie, >18 watts), but for now, most phones only support 15 watts at maximum. So, yes, you can charge your Motorola Nexus 6 with a Samsung Galaxy S6 Adaptive Fast Charger and still get basically the same charging speed as you would with the Motorola Turbo Charger 2.0 that the Nexus 6 comes with. And that, of course, brings us to an important question: why call them different things if they're all really the same? Yes, your Nexus 6 will charge just as quick with a Samsung unit. The answer, and there really is not much more to it than this, is marketing. Motorola would like you to buy their charger from them, and Samsung would you like you to buy their charger from them. That's pretty much it. Now, we can talk about whose charger contains higher-quality components and whose has a higher failure rate, but those things aren't relevant to the actual performance of the chargers themselves. This is my point: you don't need an expensive, OEM-branded quick charger to get the maximum charging speed out of your phone. Qualcomm's own Quick Charge 2.0 documentation even has a list of Quick Charge 2.0-certified chargers (granted, it's far from complete). This Aukey charger is around sixteen bucks on Amazon. Why, then, does a Motorola Turbo Charger cost $35 while something like this Aukey Quick Charge 2.0 charger is just $16 on Amazon? Certainly, you could probably argue that the Motorola charger is subject to more scrutinizing quality control, potentially contains superior electrical components - and I cannot stress enough that even this may not be true, I haven't torn these chargers apart - and as such may have a lower failure rate than an off-brand charger. Beyond that? They're basically the same thing. (For the record, I tested the Aukey I bought on a Nexus 6, Galaxy S6, Galaxy Note 4, Note Edge, ASUS ZenFone 2, HTC One M8, M9, and LG G4 - all of them recognized it as a fast charger.) Can the extra money for the official charger be justified, then? Let me put it this way, even if you bought two of these Aukeys - a brand which I am not specifically endorsing, it's just a random one I picked up on Amazon - and a month later one of them failed, you'd still come out ahead versus the OEM-branded charger. Here's a list of ones with at least 15W of output that seem to review well on Amazon, and there are likely even more well-reviewed ones out there on other online shopping sites. Anker 18W Quick Charge 2.0 wall charger Aukey 18W Quick Charge 2.0 wall charger CHOETECH 18W Quick Charge 2.0 wall charger Keedox 18W Quick Charge 2.0 wall charger iVoler 18W Quick Charge 2.0 wall charger While I'm certainly not deaf to the argument that shoddy electronics exist, we've also got to realize that hundreds upon hundreds of companies are now building smartphone wall chargers, and there are only so many things you can really screw up before your Amazon reviews end up in the gutter. And remember, you're only going to need this charger, probably, for a couple years - does it really matter if the Motorola one is more likely to last for five? Let's also not forget that with the transition to Type C USB connectors on the horizon, full-sized USB ports on wall chargers may become a thing of the past within the next few years. Another practical question about quick charging that you might have: how can I tell if the charger that came with my phone is a quick charger? This is actually easier than you might think. Among the various certifications and product info on the charger, you should find something resembling the word "output" - and next to that word you should see a voltage and an amperage, if not usually two or more voltages and amperages. Quick Charge 2.0 chargers generally have at least two ratings, one of which should be 15W or more (multiply the voltage by amperage to get your wattage - in this example its 1.67x9, which is roughly 15W). You can see this Galaxy S6 / Note 4 charger has a peak output of approximately 15W You'll find some that claim to be 18 watts (like all of the Amazon models I linked), or 12V at 1.5A and 9V at 2A, but as far as I can tell, no smartphone actually supports that amount of power yet, as no major smartphone manufacturer is shipping an 18-watt charger. But if your charger does support up to 18 watts, in theory you could be a little more future-proofed when phones with this charging speed start to come out. There are even 20 and 30W examples on Amazon, but again, no phone can take that much power just yet, and the end device will only accept the maximum level it's capable of handling, which for now appears to top out around 15W. As to the whole 60W claim Qualcomm makes, well, that's really just theoretical - I don't think there even is a single-port 60W Quick Charge 2.0 charger yet, and 60W is a lot of power - more than enough even for many laptops. No smartphone is remotely close to supporting that amount of power input yet, so don't worry: 15 watts is generally the maximum these phones can accept, at least for now. I hope this article's given you a little more insight on quick charging, how it works, and how you can save some money on your next charger - I know it was a learning experience for me simply in writing it. Update: As suggested by one of our commenters, if you're looking for a good USB cable to go along with your quick charger, Monoprice has 24AWG microUSB cables that should handle all that current with no problem. Tags adaptive fast charging quick charge 2.0 quick charging turbo charging what is adaptive fast charging what is quick charge what is turbo charging subscribe ... Alex Lord I've been wondering this, does Anker poweriq (essentially just a load balancer imo) have the ability to deliver the 'Charge 2.0' my S6 Edge requires? It can certainly deliver enough power, but is it the charger circuitry that TELLS it to create the higher pull from the device if you get my drift? Otherwise I'd imagine the Anker would deliver a standard charge? Jarrett Lennon Kaufman PowerIQ cannot deliver Quick Charge 2.0. As you noted, IQ mainly just negotiates with the device to give it however much power it can handle based on its abilities. Quick Charge 2.0 makes use of the additional pins/wires meant for things like data transmission to simultaneously send up to three separate voltages of power simultaneously to the device, allowing it send way more power than the USB spec is capable of. Anker does make devices that have QC2.0 that then fall back on PowerIQ when plugged into a device that doesn't support it, though. David Ruddock Uhhhhhhhhhhhhh no. The output spec on the charger is measured at the port. Theoretically, it could require more INPUT to achieve the specified output if it was particularly inefficient, but no, if it says it does 15W of output, it should do 15W of output. Loss over the cable / at the power management interface on the phone may happen, yes, but this is splitting hairs. As to 'screwing up the battery,' modern phones have pretty capable power management systems and would likely cut the charge if unsafe fluctuations or surges were detected (within reason). Obviously, do not buy from sellers with poor reputations or from sellers who claim to be selling "OEM" products at suspiciously discounted prices. Just be a smart consumer, and you'll probably be just fine. Theo when i say electricity loss i don't mean lower output capacity. every charger input some watt (f.e. x watts)and ouputs 15 or 18. x is always greater than the ouput. quality charger will input 15.something max 16 watt and ouput 15. a lower quality will input more, ergo there is a possibility that a cheap charger will cost more (more money to the electric bill) than an expensive charger in it lifetime. like the power supplies of computers. they come rated bronze,silver,golden. bronze has 80+ % efficiency silver 85+ and gold 90 N8 That's a good point. Bad chargers DO exist. But if you stick with third-party names that have a decent reputation, or wait a few weeks and pick ones that have a good spread of reviews leaning mostly toward the 4- and 5-star off a reputable site, the chances of actually getting a dud are very low. Saving $20 to get an Aukey, Anker, or other respected third-party charger with 400 4+ star reviews from Amazon is a wise choice. QC2.0 supports up to 60W, and the tech is all in the power controller, not the actual port. USB-C obviously gives more headroom, but I think QC2.0 will be around for a while yet unless a more efficient system is discovered. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman Perhaps, but from what I've read about QC2.0, one of the main things that differentiates it is its ability to draw different wattages across different sets of pins, including those normally used for data. So it redirects what would have been data pins to charging, and the QC2.0 charger is designed to deal with that. Those elements would be unnecessary with USB-C, as it's already built, from the beginning, to transmit massive amounts of power without any tricks. David Ruddock Yeah, I don't know what the underlying IP is. If it literally is just that Qualcomm has a patent on hijacking the data pins, then yeah, USB-C may just replace it entirely. But if Qualcomm has patents on things like the scaling technique, battery read method, etc in the power controller, then it could be a different story. Qualcomm is very intentionally obtuse about how all of this works, sadly. Jarrett Lennon Kaufman Yeah, my assumption is that SOME of the underlying technology will carry over. But I don't think the pin-out system will match up, which is why I strongly suspect the current QC2.0 chargers won't be able to charge USB-C devices that are designed for high-speed charging at their full capacity. What is it about? andy_o The Android 5.1 update (version 3.0 for NV) was so buggy they pulled it. It's snappier, but they effed up fast charging, it now charges at 5V only like a regular tablet. Among other things they screwed were USB OTG (you need to restart the tablet with the thing plugged for it to work, but that disables charging, for which you need to restart again), and somehow it seems to be messing with a lot of people's speakers, though I haven't seen that personally. Android Developer I see. So what happened to those that have updated to this problematic version? Thanks for the info! blahmoomoo Hmm, based on my experience with the 2014 Moto X (with the Motorola Turbo Charger, which has the 12v mode), it does appear to use the 12v mode of the turbo charger. I can tell because, when charging up from nothing, I saw noticeable charging rate changes at 50% and 75%. Which suggested to me that the Moto X is tuned to use 12v from 0-50%, 9v from 50-75%, and 5v above that. The phone also isn't nearly as hot while it's charging on the turbo charger above 50%, though still warmer than when charging on standard high current 5v. David Ruddock I'm not sure what your point is here. 12v at 1.2A is 15W. 9V at 1.67A is 15W. blahmoomoo Snip. blahmoomoo Never mind, the Turbo Charger doesn't have an 18w mode. The 12v mode is 1.2a, so more like 15w. Somehow charges faster than the 9v mode though. David Ruddock That's the saturation effect. The voltage goes down as the battery saturates because the lithium ion cells can't go into overvoltage. I've tried to think of an analogy for this effect but it's kind of.. abstract. But basically, yes, it will slow down when it gets to a certain point, the tl;dr being that's just how lithium ion batteries work. Cool Good analogy: You slow down filling a large jug of water as it reaches the top so it won't overflow. At least that's how I fill large jugs of water. Maybe I'm weird. David Ruddock That works. blahmoomoo The 9v mode is also ~15w, but I guess there is some battery chemistry reason why that charges slower (and is sufficient to avoid overvoltage) compared to the same-powered 12v mode. You should note though, that CABLES DO MATTER. Every el-cheapo ebay cable isn't supported for quick charging. They usually allow about 700mAh to pass through. You need high quality cables that probably came with your smartphone in order for quick charging to work. I have done several tests with my Note 4 with several cables and an adapter that meters the output Amperage. Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Micro-24-28-Quick-Charge-Cable/dp/B01ND11FZS/ Monoprice: http://disq.us/url?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.monoprice.com%2FSearch%2FIndex%3Fkeyword%3Dmicro%2Busb%2B28%252F24%3ATiBvP2yHxaYBIp3FVpLnjopnfrE&cuid=1370072 Tyler Humphreys Cables shouldn't affect Quick Charge specifically. Generally you need better cables to support higher amperage (not mAh as that is capacity and is irrelevant to cables), and Quick Charge has slightly lower amperage since it ups the voltage instead. That being said, standard USB is only 500mV so cheap cables might not handle more than that, but Quick Charge hasn't changed anything in that regard. I was wondering why my ThinkPad Tablet 2 was always charging slowly at home, regardless of which AC adapter was being used, but I eventually narrowed it down to the thin-gauge Samsung-brand MicroUSB cable. vibhor nice article Thanks for information cabbieBot Good post, David. One thing I never took into account until I ran across a random XDA post explaining it is cable quality. I figured there had to be a middle ground between expensive OEM cords and the ones I've been buying off of monoprice that are cheaper than my exes. Basically, most USB cables sold are 24 or 28 AWG (American Wire Gauge) in regards to their thickness (higher = thinner), and the logic is that a fatter cable is going to bring more current and probably last longer too. There's also the issue of cables that do data transfer/sync also will charge slower than one that is just supplying juice Suffice to say, I'm waiting for these to come in from Amazon right now and hoping they work as well as I think they will. I don't mind spending 8 bucks on a good cable if it'll do the job and not break on me: "PortaPow Specialised 5ft 20AWG Charge Only Micro USB Cable" http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0088HTYUE "PortaPow Specialised 3.3ft 20AWG Charge+Sync Micro USB Cable" http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00RQ5AZJ8 David Ruddock Good suggestions! Wildcard One of the reviewers said those dont work with QC "Well the cable works and charges, however, DO NOT PURCHASE THIS CABLE IF YOU PLAN ON USING THESE CABLES WITH A "FAST CHARGING" CAPABLE DEVICE/CHARGER. I purchased these cables to use with the Anker 18W USB Wall Charger with Qualcomm Quick Charge 2.0 Technology charger, as I have a device capable of "fast charging." These cables provided the standard charge (5V), but would not work with the "Fast Charging" (9-12V) technology. So in summary, works as a regular charging cable. These cables will not work with a "Fast Charging" device or charger." andrey3000 Correct.. you need a "standard" USB cable to use QC. The so called "charging"-cables doesn't support more than 1.5A. Or to be more precise according to the USB standard a connected device must not draw more than 1.5A when connected to a "old school" USB charging port where the data pins are shorted. Modern chargers (including QC) use the D- and D+ lines to negotiate voltage and ampere with the connected device. X-47B David Ruddock: nice artcile, but a slight error. Samsung doesn't use or license Qualcomm's Quick Charge or Quick Charge 2.0. The technology is similar, and you can use QC 2.0 adapters with Samsung's phones with both Qualcomm and Exynos. Josep Ali Beside Samsung, who's adopted this Qnovo adaptive technology ? Asus ? Matthew Fry Didn't cover vooc flash charging though. For anyone curious, the vooc is different in that it stays at 5V and dumps a shitload of current down. 5A worth. The charger and the cable are very expensive and needed. Rod Hosilyk Nice article David - very timely with much needed info. In addition to what you discuss, there are many confusing marketing terms claiming to be "fast chargers". For instance, "USB charger provides high power rapid charge for cell phones, etc....an intelligent charger using Auto Detect Technology yada yada...". In fact these are nothing more than 5 volt USB chargers capable of supplying higher current - typically over 2 amps per port. The claim further goes on to say they "automatically detect and provide the exact current needed to rapidly charge your device". Well, duh, a device will only take the current it needs so this statement is double talk. In summary, if the "adaptive fast charger" doesn't supply 5 volts PLUS at least one higher voltage, it probably doesn't comply with the Qualcom 2.0 standard and therefore will not charge at the greater speeds it provides. Josep Ali But the USB meter showed it draws 9V....double talk ? Michael Also through Amazon a Brit company, PortaPow, offers a 20 gage charging cable in both its red tipped USB charge only cable and its green tipped. USB data/charge. To make use of Quick Charge 2.0 you will need the green tipped data/charge cable. Because you have to have a minor data connection, between the phone and the charger, for Quick Charge 2.0 to work. Michael I wish they would make it more clear if they did all of these charging speed tests with the phone powered down/off or just in idle mode. Michael Another good charging cable on Amazon, for Quick Charge 2.0, is the green tipped ones from PortaPow. The charging wire in it is 20 gauge. But for quick charge 2.0 do not confuse it with the red tipped charging only cables. Those will not work at QC speeds with quick charge 2.0 as you need the data connection, between the phone and the charger, and the red tip charge only cables will not provide that. You will only get conventional charging speeds out of the charger if you use them. That being said, I very much do like the red tipped charge only cables for use with conventional chargers and for extra security when using public computers. They're both output 15W of power, but is it the same? Microchip 15 watts is all they can "take?" Apparently this article and even the responses are flawed in so many ways with leaps and bounds of misinformation. Firstly, chargers work on the basis of detecting "voltage" not "wattage" in terms of deciding when they get turned on and off. One poster writes the size of the wire matters. The size of the wire carrying the electrical path is not particularly relevant as we are not boosting a car battery. I could post some charts indicating the electrical resistance of wire based on wire diameter, but a few millimeters here or there is like comparing which grain of salt is larger than the other. It's currently carrying capacity when compared the diameter and size of these wall charger cables with one another is entirely insignificant. Comparing 4 AWG battery booster cables with cell phone wall charger cables is another story . Heres how it works regardless of wall charger cables size. When a battery reaches a predetermined maximum voltage, a sensing circuit turns off the charge going to the battery. This is regardless of the "wattage" ratings of the charging unit itself. Secondly, fast charging a battery has negative consequences for the battery regardless of what fancy technological name you would like to attach to it or how it's being accomplished. The laws of physics hasn't changed just because we call it "speed charging" or whatever. The reality is the battery will not cycle for as long therefore you wiill be expecting to replace the battery sooner. Of course, this is good for battery manufacturers from a marketing perspective. The faster you can wear and burn out your battery the better it is for them. The article isn't entirely wrong though. You will indeed enjoy "speed charging" at least until the battery decides to cook itself to death which is probably a few months or so. Doesn't much matter since we are a disposable society anyways. After all why should things last any longer than the next upgraded phone model released 6 months from now? We are reaching the the point of disposable phones so cooking the batteries in a short time is incentive for maximizing profits. So be sure to cook your battery as fast as you can so you can throw it out sooner than we have ever done before. We can just call this charging feature "advanced technology." Is it... Is it really? Like I said before, this article is loaded with misinformation. Flodis The article feels a bit backwards. The charger is not about some power about to hit your phone. The important thing is what voltage is available at the smartphone input connector, Smartphones adapts how much current they use depending on voltage. One major component is the cable between charger and phone. The volage drop is proportional to current X cable resistance. The phone will try to use as much current as possible given the state of charge, battery temperature etc. But not to any extent - It will monitor input voltage. If you have a weak charger that drop in voltage when phone tries to use the required current the phone will try less current and charge time increases. Same if cable voltage drop is significant. It will reduce the charge current until input voltage is fairly ok. What you need is not power. You need a charger capable of the current the phone requires and you need a solid and short USB cable. Look for 2.5A chargers with 5.2Volt output. Then you have headroom for cable voltage drop and even if you loose 0.2Volts in the cable at 2.5A there is still 5.0V at the phone input and it will think this is a rock solid power supply. Even a 5V, 20A charger is useless if cable is thin and long. If cable voltage drop is too large phone will reduce charge current to not overheat or overload what it thinks is a weak power source. MAKAVELI Thanks mate Ga ton I read al that and still don't know if I can use turbo charger 2 on a normal bluetooth headphone!? Or will I ruin its battery? Specter29 Thank you for sharing this ^ ^ David T This article is already out of date as it excludes the new USB C 5V 3A used by Google phones and tablets... but so confusing that there's now multiple standards for quick charging. Pedram Roshan Does the cable need to be a fast charge cable or can you use a regular one? mbcls not all cable are the same. when you plugged in the phone, if it shows "fast charging", you're good. if it shows "cable charging", you need a better cable. Foxtrot Charlie Does quick charge mean quick discharge? Someone told me that if i have time to charge with a non fast charger that it will be slower but the phone will also hold a charge longer; such as a quality vs quantity? sharamall Two complaints about this article: First: I have a Nexus 6, and my mother has a Galaxy 7. Her charger will NOT turbo charge my device, only my OEM Motorola charger does. How come you say any charger will work? Second: this article is missing many important details. Is the USB cord relevant or just the power adapter? (only power adapter I think) What is the downside to turbo charging? (makes phone really hot; can throttle phone's CPU and charging rate if it isn't cool) Does the Apple‚Ñ¢ Lightning‚Ñ¢ cable have an equivalent technology? (seems so) Ben Favored Son Wait, you ended abruptly, without explaining the importance of using good USB cable between charger and phone. My Android One smartphone came with a fast charger and its technology being compatible with the Quick Charge 2.0 by Qualcomm as stated and explained in the users guide. A few months after this, I came across the Ampere app at the market and tested the current the battery was charging at and the current was between 800ma to 900ma. though it would at times go down to 600ma, and even 400ma but generally stayed between 800ma to 900ma. What was quite interesting was that the Ampere support page discussed how dependent charging current is on the Charger, Charging software in the phone, and on the Cable. Ampere actually was encouraging users of the app to test the best combination of Charger and Cable with the phone for the best optimum charging combination. This was basically one of Ampere app's objectives. I had gone through 1 cheap tablet and an Asus Transformer and even had a couple more USB cables lying around that came with some forgettable gadget I bought, and also a couple of cheap smartphones and so I started using the same charger that came with my Android One with this cable, then that cable, and after testing all the cables. I was surprised and amazed at what a big difference in charging current was between using the original cable that came with my Android One phone with the other cables. The Asus Cable was charging my phone at a constant rate between 1,150ma to 1,200ma. I never attained these levels of charging with the original cable. The other cables were charging at almost the same as the original albeit in a narrower and more stable 800-850ma. A couple of cables from cheap phones performed worst from 40-690ma. The original cable performance was quite dismal. I couldn't imagine shipping an Android One with a substandard cable. Then again, Android One is generally cheap but still, I still expected better quality than this this now considered piece of wire that came with my Android One. I think its important to explain the virtues of using a good USB cable connecting charger, which is plugged to a wall socket, to the phone to deliver a stable charge, and at optimum levels. You need to test what you have to find out. atro430 Great Article, Helped me decide if i should buy this product : https://www.amazon.com/Charge-TOPGREENER-TU1152QC-2-ports-Charger/dp/B01F4HBFHA/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1472159013&sr=8-2&keywords=quick+charge+usb+charger+outlet danwat1234 The animated GIFs on this article is eating up the battery life on my laptop... stop it ISIAH WOLK my business partner wanted SSA-7050-F4 several days ago and discovered a business that hosts an online forms database . Scott Applewhite US 18:57 30.03.2017(updated 21:10 30.03.2017) Get short URL 21189160 US House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes learned about the surveillance of President Donald Trump's presidential campaign team from a whistleblower source, Speaker Paul Ryan said in an interview on Thursday. WASHINGTON (Sputnik)¬†‚Äî Ryan noted that he advised Nunes to¬†add the newly discovered facts about¬†the surveillance of¬†Trump Tower to¬†the existing investigation into¬†Russia's alleged meddling in¬†2016 US presidential election. "He had told me that a whistleblower type person had given him some information that was new, that spoke to¬†the last administration and part of¬†this investigation," Ryan told CBS News. ¬© AP Photo/ J. Scott Applewhite Nunes Apologizes to Intel Committee for Briefing Trump on SurveillanceOn March 22, Nunes told reporters that the information about¬†Trump team was "incidentally collected" during¬†the transition period. Following the announcement, the intelligence committee chair visited the White House and briefed the US president on¬†the findings. Later, Nunes explained why he decided to¬†brief the press and US President Donald Trump on¬†new intelligence information before¬†telling the ranking Democrat on¬†the committee. These actions triggered immediate criticism of¬†the panel's members, who have not been notified in¬†advance about¬†the additional documents related to¬†Trump's wiretapping claim. On Tuesday, several prominent Democrats called on¬†congressman Nunes to recuse himself from¬†the probe into¬†alleged Russia's election interference. On March 4, Trump took to¬†Twitter to¬†accuse Obama of¬†having his Trump Tower headquarters' "wires tapped" prior to¬†the 2016 presidential election, describing this as¬†the former administration's "new low. The president went on¬†to compare the alleged surveillance to McCarthyism and the Watergate scandal. The claims have been rejected by¬†Obama's representative. The US House and Senate Intelligence Committees have found no credible evidence to¬†support Trump's claims. ...
